transcription.text: The carbon fibre/polycarbonate composite material used in the manufacture of these parts enables the camera body to be incredibly strong and rigid, but also very lightweight.

What do the Avengers, Jason Bourne and the Expendables have in common? Aside from heroes saving the day, these film franchises all feature frenetic action sequences filmed on the Blackmagic Pocket Cinema Camera. The key isn’t just the Hollywood-quality 6K resolution (it helps though), but the size of the camera. Filmmakers have strapped them to motorbikes, cars, trucks, boats and even tanks, with their size allowing minimal rigging and creative approaches to capturing breathtaking action. What also helps is that they’re made from carbon fibre/polycarbonate composite material so they’re super strong but also lightweight. First sketched out and designed on 3D CAD (Computer Assisted Design) software, prototypes are then made from 3D prints while the internal components are miniaturised to ensure hand-held use without losing their cinematic quality.

The Pocket Cinema Camera 6K is the world’s lightest and most portable 6K digital film camera, designed specifically for independant filmmakers, TV and web broadcasters.

It offers Hollywood image quality and professional features in an affordable, ultra-portable and familiar DSLR format.

Costume designer Edie Kurzer used a combination of vintage garments and original pieces for the Picnic at Hanging Rock (2018) costumes. As we can see from this costume sketch, Mrs Appleyard’s purple fete outfit was fabricated from scratch, while the reference materials illustrate some of the details that went into Edie Kurzer’s design of the garments. The costume sketch and accompanying mood board of Victorian-era collars show how Kurzer gathered a body of historical reference points while crafting the original garments, like the stunning purple and gold jacket that goes with Mrs Appleyard’s fete costume. On this reference board, there are several designs that closely mimic the high, V-shaped collar of the final jacket.

work.title: Picnic at Hanging Rock purple fete and mourning dress design materials

transcription.text: Edie Kurzer’s sketches demonstrate the level of detail and care that goes into each of the costumes in Picnic at Hanging Rock (2018). The time frame of the series is limited, and costumes recur in flashbacks and memories throughout the show. As a result, we can see that each costume was designed to be worn in several ways. Here, we see that the bright burgundy exterior of Mrs Appleyard’s (Natalie Dormer) dress, which she wears in the infamous Valentine’s Day photo, gives way to a dark underskirt and shirt, with the suggestion that it can be worn with a sunhat and sunglasses in less formal scenes.

work.title: Picnic at Hanging Rock (2018) burgundy Valentine’s Day dress and picnic dresses design materials

transcription.text: Rectangular grand piano and piano stool, the major props used in the production of the film 'The Piano', Jan Chapman producer, Jane Campion director; 1993.
Piano key with inscription. Wood object, painted white. A prop from the film 'The Piano', Jan Chapman producer, Jane Campion director; 1993.

How the media produces news changed dramatically when bystanders captured the 2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami on handheld cameras. After obtaining the footage, news outlets circulated it around the globe. Today, social media allows spectators to share footage and images of world events instantly.

work.title: Phi Phi Island after the Indian Ocean tsunami

transcription.text:
This is one of the first devices to create the illusion of motion from still images. A stroboscopic cardboard disc featuring a sequence of slightly different pictures is mounted on a handle. Around the disc’s rim, above the images, are equally spaced slots. Nothing magical happens when you spin the disc, but the images flicker to life when you peer through the slots at the disc’s reflection in a mirror.

Invented almost simultaneously in 1832 by Joseph Plateau in Brussels and Simon von Stampfer in Berlin, the phenakistiscope was an important predecessor of the zoetrope, and its infinitely looping animation is reminiscent of today’s GIFs.
